Campbell is a Carbon Expert with Rainforest Alliance. Campbell has experience on both the technical and policy sides of REDD+. Campbell's recent professional experience includes consulting work for GIZ Philippines performing carbon stock assessments of different forest types including agroforestry and plantation systems, as well as work centered on reforestation in Sri Lanka for the Environmental Leadership and Training Initiative. He additionally has worked for Climate Focus on LULUCF policy issues. From 2009-2011 Campbell pursued his Master of Forestry from the Yale University School of Forestry and Environmental Studies. During this time period he concentrated heavily on REDD+. This period included a variety of forestry projects including developing a management plan for Connecticut forest preserve, planning timber sales in a New England hardwood forest, and designing and modelling carbon sequestration potential of agroforestry systems for the Nature Conservancy’s Global Climate Team. Prior to his time at Yale, Campbell worked in The Gambia for over two years as a Peace Corps Volunteer designing and implementing a wide variety of forestry, agroforestry, and agricultural projects. In addition to his Master of Forestry degree, he holds a M.A. in Environmental Studies from St. Mary’s College. Campbell speaks Pulaar and Wolof and has experience with Spanish.

findings_from_verification_field_audit The management system is structured in the form of a pyramid wherein the individual sites managed by a farm manager under whom all the operations including those related to the forest carbon project are being implemented. The farm managers report to the project manager who in turn reviews all the operations being reported at the site level and is responsible for the overall project management. The project manager reports to VP (Plantations) who is the overall responsible person for financial as well as technical performance of the project. The responsibilities for the management team are well defined and the project team has remained unchanged throughout the forest carbon program such that they are well versed in performing the necessary tasks and documentation related to the project. All documents being generated at the project site is reviewed at two levels: at the project manager level and at the Head Office (VP) level. The project is being monitored in an ongoing manner and a monthly report is prepared on the basis of which project performance is reviewed. Based on these findings, the auditors concluded that the project’s management system for monitoring and reporting is suitable.

findings_from_verification_field_audit The inventory techniques used to calculate project net removals include measurement of DBH and height of trees in sample plots. Tree height is measured with a graduated bamboo and a clinometer, the use of which was demonstrated in the field by the PIL field staff. Tree girth is measured at breast height at marked points on the trees. The data is being stored in hardcopy as well as electronically. The data is reviewed by the plantation manager for quality control. The auditors took sample measurements of trees from six sample plots in the field, which indicated that recorded measurements are accurate. These techniques conform with those identified in the validated monitoring plan outlined within the validated PD.

col_2 The Project Proponent, Prakash Industries Limited (PIL), have undertaken reforestation of 282.35 ha of degraded wastelands in Durg, Raigarh and Rajnandgaon districts of Chhattisgarh State in India. The land is assumed to have remained as barren land in the absence of project activities. Land areas utilized by the project have been purchased by local farmers, which have been planted with native tree species of Gmelina arborea and Albizzia lebbeck. The plantation was initiated in 2002 and was validated as a VCS project in 2011. During the first monitoring period (15 June 2002 to 31 December 2009), 36784 tCO2e were sequestered by the project activity. The current monitoring period that this report assesses is from 1 January 2010 through 31 July 2012. During this period net GHG removals by the project were 19,699 tCO2e. As the buffer risk factor is 11%, the total VCU issuance after buffer deduction is 17,532 VCUs. In June-2014, an external stakeholder identified an error in the use of the root to shoot default factor used by the proponent resulting in a reduction in the GHG removals and VCU issuance for this monitoring period and for the previous monitoring period. The total overissuance of VCUs for the monitoring period corresponding to this report was 1589. The total overissuance across all monitoring periods was 8789 VCUs. This has since been corrected in this report which is now based on the monitoring report, version 3.5 from 05 December 2014.

data_/_parameter: Description:; plot_location The permanent sample plot locations have been chosen on the basis of stratified random sampling and are located systematically with a random start, which is considered good practice in GPG-LULUCF. The plots are selected by the following steps: i) The project area is first stratified at the primary level on the basis of soil types as illustrated in Table 43. ii) The second level of stratification is done on the basis of species and their age (date of planting). iii) Thus the stratum which has been used as a unit to select plot location is one species of a specific age, eg. Gmelina arborea planted in 2002-03. iv) The tree nearest to the entrance of the plantation is taken as the starting point, irrespective of the direction in which the entrance lies. ―Entrance of plantation‖, implies the main gate of the plantation, which is fixed throughout the project and prominently displayed. v) Next every tree at an interval of ten trees (i.e. 1st tree, 12th tree, 23rd tree and so on in each row) of each row is marked as the reference trees. This is done to prevent bunching up of sampled trees and avoid bias is by concentrating at any one place. vi) Then, the reference trees to be used for sampling are randomly picked up from the list of trees marked earlier with the help of a random number generator. vii) Keeping the reference tree as the centre, a square of 6mx6m is marked and the eight trees surrounding the reference tree are marked A to H in clock-wise direction. Thus each sample plot consists of nine trees, viz. the reference tree and eight surrounding trees. The geographical position (GPS coordinate), administrative location, stratum and stand, series number of each sample plot shall be recorded and archived. It has been ensure that the sampling plots are evenly distributed in the stratum.

auditor(s) Kenichi Shono; qualifications Mr. Shono has broad experience in forest management and conservation including project coordination, research and policy analysis. He holds a Master of Environmental Management in Forest Science and Management from the Yale School of Forestry and Environmental Studies. He has extensive field experience in Southeast Asia, Central America and USA. Mr. Shono first gained experience as field researcher conducting an ecological study on big-leaf mahogany in Central America for CIFOR. Subsequently, he coordinated a research project on forest restoration in Singapore for the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute. From 2005 to 2008, Mr. Shono worked as Forestry Officer at FAO where he was involved in various programmes and projects related to sustainable forest management in Asia-Pacific, covering topics such as forest restoration, climate change, forest financing, reduced impact logging, and forest policy and economics. Currently, Mr. Shono is Technical & Operations Director and Senior Forestry Specialist at Hatfield. In addition to his role as one of the company directors, he manages and provides technical inputs to a range of projects including biodiversity assessment, land rehabilitation, forest management auditing, forests and climate change, forest policy analysis and studies on the forest industry. He has led many audits/assessments of FSC FM, HCVF and forest carbon projects for Rainforest Alliance. Kenichi has completed ISO 9001 lead auditor training in November 2010.

summary: The project activity involves plantation on 282.35 ha of degraded land in Chhattisgarh state of India and the capture of carbon from the atmosphere in trees. Carbon pools included in the project are aboveground biomass and belowground biomass. M/s Prakash Industries Limited has commissioned the TÜV NORD JI / CDM Certification Program to carry out the assessment of Risk Analysis a (along with Validation and Verification) of the Project “Reforestation of degraded land in Chhattisgarh, India” located in Durg, Raigarh and Rajnandgaon districts of Chhattisgarh state in India, with regard to the requirements of VCS version 3.0. The assessment is based on the draft Non-Permanence Risk Report/RR1/, revised Non-Permanence Risk Report/RR2/, the project description provided in the validated PD/PD/, the validation report/VR/ and supporting documents/RISK/ made available to the TÜV NORD JI/CDM CP by the project participant. In the course of the verification fifteen (15) Corrective Action Requests (CARs), five (5) Clarification requests were raised and successfully closed. No Forward Action Requests (FARs) were raised. As the result of the assessment, the verifier confirms that the AFOLU buffer credits are calculated without material misstatements in a conservative and appropriate manner. TÜV NORD JI/CDM CP herewith confirms that the project in accordance with the requirements for validation conclusions set out in the VCS Standard version 3 for risk analysis and buffer determination. This report is based on the positive outcome from the assessment of version 3 of the non-permanence risk report evaluation documentation dated 20-10-2011. The non-permanence risk rating for the project is assessed to be 13 which correspond to the buffer reduction of 13%. Therefore GHG removals eligible to be issued as VCUs are 87%.

n_cr#:_04/13 The analysis of financial viability provided in the Non-Permanence Risk Report incorporates expected income from timber through harvesting to determine the break-even point of the project. However, during audit visit, the project proponent stated that no harvesting has taken place and that there are currently no plans to conduct any harvesting in the future. Financial calculations in Excel format provided to the auditors (PIL_AR_Financial_121012.xls) also consider expected income from timber harvesting. Cash flow and project breakeven point provided in the Non-Permanence Risk Report is therefore contradictory to the actual project implementation.

findings_from_verification_field_audit The quality of inventory is being managed through reviewing of data at multiple levels of the management. The data at each plantation site is collected under the supervision of the plantation manager who collects the data and sends the same along with reports on other project parameters in the monthly progress report. The report is then reviewed by the project manager, who verifies at least 30% of the inventory data through re-measurement of trees in the field as a QA/QC process. The data is then sent to the VP Plantations for final review and reporting. During the field visit, the reported data was checked by physical measurement in the sample plots and the data was found to be accurate. Based on these findings, the audit team determined that the project has implemented QMS effectively and the inventory accuracy is being met.

findings_from_review_on_field_audit Operational lifetime of the validated VCS AFOLU ARR project activity is sixty-four years (64 years 00 months 00 days) from the project start date ending in 2066. This period spans six rotation ages of the plantation beyond which the project is to be converted into a conservation plantation. The land is privately-owned and there are no land disputes as verified by the auditors through community interviews. Hence, there are no uncertainties over project tenure. It was observed during the site visit that PIL has not conducted any significant harvesting. Only light thinning has been carried out, with the thinned trees being regenerated through coppice. Therefore, the available evidence at this time indicates that the proponent is allowing regrowth and the project is expected to continue for the 64-year timeline as defined in the project management plan.
